Polish health authority begins to issue guidance to travellers returning from Wuhan and the broader region: https://gis.gov.pl/aktualnosci/komunikat-dla-podrozujacych-warszawa-25-stycznia-2020-r-opracowano-na-podstawie-danych-ecdc-oraz-who/

One article from a care home:  Already in mid-February, in order to protect the charges, especially taking into account their age, the center was closed to visitors and procedures recommended by the Chief Sanitary Inspectorate were introduced, including temperature measurement, the entrance of staff to the center through a separate entrance, or the closure of the center for visitors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200813112653/https://www.rmf24.pl/raporty/raport-koronawirus-z-chin/polska/news-koronawirus-w-malopolskim-domu-opieki-wiekszosc-podopiecznyc,nId,4634538
Health authority launches a 24/7 coronavirus hotline and a broader public information campaign: https://gis.gov.pl/aktualnosci/calodobowa-infolinia-nfz-o-koronawirusie/
Polish Prime Minister announces screening measures at Czech and German borders: https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/premier-wdrozymy-kontrole-sanitarne-min-na-granicy-z-niemcami-i-czechami
Prime Minister announces closure of all large public gatherings https://www.tvp.info/47054732/premier-podjeto-decyzje-o-odwolaniu-wszystkich-imprez-masowych
Poland announces closure of all schools and pre-schools from March 12-25 https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zawieszenie-zajec

Health minister recommends social distancing, and that everyone 'stay at home for two weeks' --- police is going to the houses of recent returnees to the country under quarantine to ensure that they are respecting their self-quarantine https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/od-dzis-wprowadzimy-stan-zagrozenia-epidemicznego

Additional funds for health care services have been released by the NHF,  using its reserve fund to increase the 2020 budget by more than PLN 1.4 billion. These funds will be allocated to cover an increase in “usual” funding for hospitals by 5% and withdrawing limits for some outpatient specialist services. Moreover, these measures were undertaken to prevent the reduction of hospital revenues due to the cancellation of services. Hospitals which have had to reduce non-COVID-19 services can apply for payments which they would have receive if they had provided these services according to their NHF contracts.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200419132908/http://prawo.sejm.gov.pl/isap.nsf/DocDetails.xsp?id=WDU20200000422

From 14 March 2020, shops located in shopping malls over 2,000 square meters are closed excluding grocery stores, drugstores, laundries and pharmacies; and all bars, restaurants, pubs, casinos and other similar places of entertainment are closed. Restaurants can, however, sell food for delivery.  https://www.premier.gov.pl/wydarzenia/aktualnosci/premier-bezpieczenstwo-zdrowotne-polakow-jest-najwazniejsze.html

No international inbound flights or trains would be allowed from March 15, except for some charter flights bringing Poles back from holidays.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/03/coronavirus-travel-restrictions-border-shutdowns-country-200318091505922.html#

The President announced during briefing that in the case of companies that decide to maintain jobs, the government will subsidize 40 percent of the average wage for each employee: https://web.archive.org/web/20200507075657/https://www.prezydent.pl/aktualnosci/wypowiedzi-prezydenta-rp/wystapienia/art,1018,wypowiedzi-prezydenta-i-premiera-po-posiedzeniu-rady-gabinetowej.html

Poland announces a large economic package of 212 billion zloty, with measures targeted at workers and businesses of all sizes; the package includes various new loan programs, salary support for firms, and tax breaks: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/tarcza-antykryzysowa-ma-ochronic-firmy-i-pracownikow-przed-skutkami-epidemii-koronawirusa; https://web.archive.org/save/https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-health-coronavirus-poland-stimulus/poland-unveils-51-billion-anti-coronavirus-package-idUKKBN2151TE; https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-18/poland-pledges-52-billion-stimulus-injection-to-fight-virus

The governments hygiene/sanitation inspectorate (in charge of coordinating COVID testing) issues its official policy on Mar 22, allowing for people symtomatic (with fever, cough) to be tested if they meet a list of conditions (e.g. returning from another country with local COVID transmission; close contact with someone who is a confirmed COVID case).     http://web.archive.org/web/20200402174409/https://gis.gov.pl/aktualnosci/definicja-przypadku-na-potrzeby-nadzoru-nad-zakazeniami-ludzi-nowym-koronawirusem-sars-cov-2/

all events and gatherings are now outlawed: 'Ban on all kinds of gatherings, meetings and events, except for those attended by the members of the immediate family or people living together.'    https://www.premier.gov.pl/en/news/news/prime-minister-in-the-battle-against-the-coronavirus-we-must-reduce-our-mobility-to-an.html

The school closures, initially slated to run until Mar 25, have been extended until April 10.   'Zmienilismy przepisy, dzieki którym mozliwe jest prowadzenie ksztalcenia na odleglosc. According to the announcement of the Polish government:  - 90% reduction rents for tenants of premises and the so-called islands in shopping malls, as long as these facilities are prohibited from operating normally;  - exemption from charging contractual penalties for - related to the epidemic - delays in the execution of tenders;  - enabling municipalities to refrain from charging real estate tax on companies that have lost their liquidity due to the coronavirus epidemic.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200507081400/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/tarcza

Any assembly, meeting, event or meeting of more than 2 persons is prohibited. This restriction does not apply to meetings with loved ones [residing together]. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200331121008/www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

People may only leave the house to go to and from work (for those in essential service jobs), volunteer on Covid-19 relief efforts, and for basic needs such as groceries, pharmacy visits, caring for loved ones. Children under teh age of 18 cannot leave the house without a legal adult guardian. https://web.archive.org/web/20200331121008/www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

People should not be traveling between cities and regions unless for essential needs including helping a loved one, or otherwise for essential service work/volunteerism https://web.archive.org/web/20200331121008/www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

On April 7, the government proposed an expansion in the coverage of budgetary measures, with an estimated budgetary cost of PLN 18 billion (0.8 percent of GDP).   https://web.archive.org/web/20200608130547/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Public transit authorities are now allowed to increase the passenger limit in public transit vehicles. How many people can use a vehicle?    As many people as there are seats (if there are only seats)  or    as many as 50% of the total number of seats and standing spots (in this case, however, half the seats must remain empty).  Example    If there are seats on the bus, they can all be occupied. If the bus has 30 seats and 70 standing spots, it can accommodate 50 people.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200720215111/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations

As of 13 June 2020, Poland have restored full border traffic within the internal borders of the European Union. This means that you can travel freely cross the internal borders of the European Union. Travelers will regain the right to free entry, exit and transit through the territory of the Republic of Poland. They do not have to quarantine.    Restriction concerns: foreigners crossing the EU's external border.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200720215111/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations

For future coding: from next Monday onwards, schools are scheduled to re-open, with no face mask requirements.   https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-health-coronavirus-poland/poland-to-reopen-schools-despite-new-coronavirus-record-idUKKBN25K1MW

According to the guidelines prepared by the ministries of health and education, a student may attend school with the chief sanitary inspector without symptoms of respiratory tract infection and when the household is not in quarantine or in isolation.    There are general hygiene practices in schools: washing your hands frequently (as soon as you come to school), protecting yourself when sneezing and coughing, and avoiding touching your eyes, nose and mouth. People entering the school building should be able to use a hand sanitizer. If it is possible, in the cloakroom, every second box should be made available for students or different hours of coming to school should be introduced.    As far as possible, work should be organized in such a way as to keep distance between people in school and to limit the concentration of students. Students and teachers do not need to wear mouth and nose masks in classroom lessons.    Almost all schools started operating on September 1, informed the head of the Ministry of National Education, Dariusz Piontkowski.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200902130152/https://niezalezna.pl/349533-niemal-wszystkie-szkoly-otwarte-rozwiazania-w-polsce-jak-w-innych-europejskich-krajach

General levels of contact tracing seem low, as:    "Just 1.9% of the Polish population have downloaded the government’s COVID-19 contact tracing app since its launch in June. That is one of the lowest levels of take-up among European countries. Such low adoption means that the app will not be effective, according to experts. The system, which cost around 2.5 million zloty (€0.6 million) to develop, has also been hit by concerns over privacy and functionality."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120143636/https://notesfrompoland.com/2020/09/11/uptake-of-covid-contact-tracing-app-under-2-in-poland-among-the-lowest-rates-in-europe/    "Contact tracing using epidemiological interviews is carried out for people who may have had contact with an infected person according to the epidemiological criteria of COVID-19 case explained above. There is no active guidance to close schools.  As for guidance within schools, children are supposed to disinfect hands frequently and keep their distance from each other. There is no requirement to wear masks, although directors have the freedom to impose such a measure for pupils moving inside the building.  https://www.politico.eu/article/despite-coronavirus-fears-poland-goes-all-in-on-re-opening-schools/ [web archive unavailable, accessed 28th September 2020]

Note: It seems like most places are allowed to open. Theatres, cinemas, operas, and ballets are permitted to operate again with special sanitary and social distancing requirements. Gyms, swimming pools, amusement parks, and children’s play areas are also allowed to open. See: https://pl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ [web archive unavailable, accessed 28th September 2020] See also: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/poland/coronavirus [web archive unavailable, accessed 28th September 2020]

Note: New 2020 budget - Wage subsidies for employees of affected businesses and self-employed persons. Businesses, regardless of their size, may apply for a three-month subsidy in the event of work stoppages or reduced working time. This subsidy covers social insurance contributions, and it ranges from 50 to 90 percent of the minimum wage for each employee, depending on recorded decrease in turnover in 2020. The subsidy includes furloughed employees. See: [web archive unavailable, accessed 28th September 2020]

Note: for other regions not covered by more restrictive measures, face coverings are required inside public buildings and locations such as churches, cinemas, hair salons, restaurants, shops, and public transport. See: https://pl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ [web archive unavailable, accessed 28th September 2020]

The following restrictions will come into effect on Saturday, October 24:     - The entire territory of Poland will become a 'red' zone;     - Restaurant activity will be limited for two weeks to serving only takeaway food;    - Grades four to eight in elementary schools will switch to remote learning;     - Secondary schools and higher learning institutions will switch to remote learning.    - Between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., children under the age of 16 will be allowed to leave their homes only in the company of an adult;    - Spectators will be banned from sporting events;    - There will be a 25-percent cap on audiences at all cultural events;    - Swimming pools, aquaparks and fitness clubs will be closed;    - Sanatoria will be closed;    - The number of people at retail premises of up to 100 square metres will be capped at five per checkout;     - The number of customers in retail premises above 100 square metres will be limited to one person per 15 square metres;    - Public transport will be limited to 50 percent of seating capacity or 30 percent of total capacity;    - Gatherings of more than five people will be banned, except for people living together in one home;    - Persons aged 70 and above are to encouraged to stay at home, apart from performing their professional activities, meeting their essential daily needs and participating in religious ceremonies.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201027185141/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

On November 3, the Ministry of Health published a strategy for fighting the pandemic during the autumn and winter months (the so-called ‘Strategy 3.0’). In terms of testing, the aim is to continue with testing of symptomatic patients. Testing is mandated for the following population groups and/or settings:  1) People with symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 infection;  2) People before the start of a spa treatment or spa rehabilitation and before admission to long-term care facilities;  3) Testing of asymptomatic patients if this is necessary as part of the epidemiological investigation in case of major outbreaks (e.g. in large workplaces);  4) Testing of symptomatic patients in the emergency wards using rapid tests, including antigen tests, in order to establish a diagnosis.  5) Implementation of antigen tests in COVID-19 diagnosing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210117202609/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/poszerzamy-strategie-walki-z-koronawirusem    https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/poland/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5%20Testing&Type=Section (archive failed)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210117202918/https://www.gov.pl/attachment/49536e92-3aca-4df8-bd3c-2bf22915564f

***Recoded from 3G to 2G; while masks are required in many public spaces, they are not required at others (see list of exemptions below)     Covering the mouth and nose in public spaces is obligatory throughout the entire country!    It is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose in such places as:    -on streets, roads and in town squares, within cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, vehicle parking areas, forest car parks,  -in buses, trams and trains,  -in shops, malls, banks, markets and post offices  -in cinemas and theatres,  -at physician’s offices, in outpatient clinics and hospitals, in massage and tattoo parlours  -in churches, at schools and universities,  -In government offices (when going there to take care of certain matters) and other civic centres.    Where is it not mandatory to cover your mouth and nose? In forests, parks, green squares, botanical gardens, historic gardens, family community gardens and on beaches as well as while travelling by private car.    Important!  Exemption from the obligation to cover the mouth and nose is limited only to persons who have a medical certificate or a document confirming:    -a pervasive developmental disorder,  -a mental disorder,  -moderate, severe or profound intellectual disability,  -difficulties in uncovering the mouth or nose on their own.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210127093533/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations

"On 13 June 2020, Poland resumed border traffic within the framework of internal borders of the EU. It means that traveling and crossing the internal borders of the EU is permitted. Travelers have regained their right to freely enter, leave or transit through the territory of the Republic of Poland. Quarantine is not required. One should consider the restrictions which are in force in a neighbouring country while planning a trip abroad."    "Important!   From 28 December 2020 to 31 January 2021, compulsory quarantine will be imposed on persons who have crossed Poland’s border (both an external and an internal EU border) by plane, bus, or other means of collective transport - for 10 days, counting from the day following the day on which the border was crossed."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210120135849/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/questions-and-answers

General levels of contact tracing seem low, as:    "Just 1.9% of the Polish population have downloaded the government’s COVID-19 contact tracing app since its launch in June. That is one of the lowest levels of take-up among European countries. Such low adoption means that the app will not be effective, according to experts. The system, which cost around 2.5 million zloty (€0.6 million) to develop, has also been hit by concerns over privacy and functionality."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120143636/https://notesfrompoland.com/2020/09/11/uptake-of-covid-contact-tracing-app-under-2-in-poland-among-the-lowest-rates-in-europe/    "Contact tracing using epidemiological interviews is carried out for people who may have had contact with an infected person according to the epidemiological criteria of COVID-19 case explained above. Data are gathered by the local sanitary inspection units. The Minister of Health publishes aggregated information about new cases, deaths and recoveries via its Twitter account. Data is not disaggregated into age groups or by geographic location."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120143626/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/poland/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.4+Monitoring+and+surveillance&Type=Section

From March 20 to April 9, the following restrictions will apply throughout Poland. They must suspend their activities:  hotels (exceptions include workers' hotels, as well as accommodation provided as part of business trips - the exact catalog of exceptions along with the required confirmation of a business trip will be included in the regulation);  shopping malls - with the exception of: grocery stores, pharmacies and drugstores, press salons, bookstores, pet stores and DIY stores. In shopping malls, they will still be able to operate, among others hairdressing, optics, banking, laundry services;  theaters, museums, art galleries (it is possible, however, to organize rehearsals and exercises, as well as online events);  cinemas (the ban on screening films also applies to cultural centers and centers)  swimming pools (except for swimming pools in entities performing medical activity and for members of the national team);  saunas, solariums, Turkish baths, slimming salons, casinos;  ski slopes;  fitness clubs and gyms;  sports facilities (may operate only for the needs of professional sports and without the participation of the public).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322231434/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/od-20-marca-w-calej-polsce-obowiazuja-rozszerzone-zasady-bezpieczenstwa

PCR and/or antigen tests are available in Poland  The Polish government provides COVID-19 testing, but only for people who display possible symptoms of COVID-19, visit a doctor, and receive a prescription for a test.  Private COVID-19 testing is available at laboratories and medical facilities throughout Poland.  Results are available within 72 hours, and the average cost of a PCR test is approximately $85 USD.  For drive-through testing center options, you can buy tests online at this website and take the code you receive to the testing center you have selected.  This website is another option in Warsaw that provides drive-through and in-home testing. This website offers an in-home testing option in Krakow.      Rapid tests are available at several airports in Poland for passengers who are traveling to or transiting countries that require a test result within four hours of flight departure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210808074444/https://pl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Lateral flow tests are available in some medical clinics for anyone with symptoms.  positive result – the patient should put in isolation; there is no need to repeat the test (due to the special epidemic situation in Poland, the national definition of a confirmed COVID-19 case of 31 October 2020 includes the possibility of laboratory confirmation of the case by detecting the SARS-CoV-2 antigen in the clinical material),  negative result – it does not rule out SARS-CoV-2 infection; for confirmation, an RT-PCR test should be performed, and until a negative molecular test result is obtained, the patient should stay in isolation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611125124/https://www.damian.pl/en/tests-for-coronavirus/

Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.    Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, at the clinic, in the hospital, at the massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, in the park, in green areas, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots,  in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210808070016/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

No policy change. Till 31 August, throughout the country, a limited number of people can travel by public transport with no more than 100% of passenger occupancy at the same time. While this is an assumed change in practice to pre-COVID, it is not a restrictive regulation.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210813074702/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

No policy change. There remains movement restrictions for pedestrians: Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians. Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210813074702/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia
No policy change. There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210808074444/https://pl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change. A 10-day entry quarantine for travelers coming into Poland continues to be in place. One of the exemptions is "are vaccinated with the full course of vaccination, 14 days have elapsed since the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the day of the last dose). Vaccination is certified by the EU digital COVID certificate or other document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination with a vaccine that has been authorized in the European Union"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210813074702/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

No new policies, but a broad range of contract relief policies continue to be in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210808083453/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/informacje-dla-beneficjentow-fe  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516011540/https://ec.europa.eu/info/live-work-travel-eu/coronavirus-response/jobs-and-economy-during-coronavirus-pandemic/state-aid-cases/poland_en    Further, Poland's government on 15 May 2021 unveiled details about a new stimulus plan designed to bolster the economy following the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.    The proposed program introduced amendments to the Polish tax system, including changes affecting individual taxpayers such as:    An increase to income for the “tax-free allowance” for low-wage earners  An increase to the threshold that triggers for individual taxpayers, application of the higher income tax bracket of 32% to PLN 120,000 (currently PLN 85,528)  An increase to the total tax and contribution burden for non-deductible health insurance contributions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210808082921/https://home.kpmg/us/en/home/insights/2021/05/tnf-poland-proposed-economic-stimulus-plan-tax-measures.html

No policy change. Coordinated public campaign continues to be in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210813074702/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia  https://web.archive.org/web/20210813084112/https://pl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change. The Polish government provides COVID-19 testing, but only for people who display possible symptoms of COVID-19, visit a doctor, and receive a prescription for a test.  Private COVID-19 testing is available at laboratories and medical facilities throughout Poland.  Results are available within 72 hours, and the average cost of a PCR test is approximately $85 USD.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210813084112/https://pl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new policies. Continued from 2 February 2, 2021 or earlier, there are two contact tracing apps in Poland (one voluntary and one mandatory). The mandatory app, “Kwarantanna domowa”, is intended for people who are subject to 10-day mandatory house quarantine. There is a clear line of communication with the subject of quarantine but unclear how far into further contact tracing the app goes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210813084639/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/kwarantanna-domowa    https://web.archive.org/web/20210813084654/https://www.nortonrosefulbright.com/-/media/files/nrf/nrfweb/contact-tracing/poland-contact-tracing.pdf?revision=f5084dcb-404f-4c7e-90fb-c56af308ca5a&la=en-pl

No new policy. Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country. Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask (ex. scarves do not apply).   Exceptions include:  In the open air, in the forest, in the park, in green areas, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots,  in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210813074702/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

No change in policy. Continued from 7 June, vaccination is available for everyone above age 12.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210808075501/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/poland-offer-covid-19-vaccinations-children-aged-12-15-says-minister-2021-06-01/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210813084112/https://pl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Safety measures are provided to schools and kindergartens. This includes disinfection stations with the function of measuring the temperature before entering the building. The equipment is purchased and distributed by the Governmental Agency for Strategic Reserves. All schools and kindergartens will receive personal protective equipment - gloves, masks, disinfectant liquid and thermometers.  The Ministry of Education and Science has prepared an information package on the organization of the vaccination process. It defines the duties and tasks of the school headmaster. These include:  organizing classes with an educator for students,  informational and educational meetings with parents,  collecting declarations from parents regarding the child's participation in vaccination,  cooperation with the vaccination center,  arranging a place for vaccination.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210902011631/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/premier-podczas-rady-gabinetowej-licze-ze-uczniowie-wroca-do-szkol-na-dobre

A deputy health minister has said Poland is now experiencing the fourth wave of the coronavirus epidemic, with 1,208 new infections and 27 deaths over the past 24 hours.  Only half of Poland's 38-million people have been fully inoculated against Covid-19 despite the fact that the government has stocked up with huge amounts of vaccines.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211001160412/https://www.thefirstnews.com/article/dep-health-minister-says-poland-already-seeing-fourth-covid-wave-25036
